comments.text:
Of the cerebrum. Not the entire brain. Heart, breathing, hormone functions 
of the brain are continuously working. The cerebrum is also always working, 
but in cyclical bursts certain areas become more stimulated.
Those bursts are fairly fast: for consciousness its 12.5 to 30 transitions 
or cycles per second. Mainly because certain parts cerebrum (thinking part 
of the brain) serve as multiple functions and often require a sequence of 
functions of other locations; so a mixture of bursting activity in 3 
locations and 4 other locations can mean entirely different concepts for 
the brain.  It can't spark all at once; like having transistors in a 
computer all turn on; you'd get nothing.
This video didn't do a very good job of explaining how false the 10% of the 
brain myth.  
You're brain is always function and being used. 16% of the neurons are 
undergoing neural bursts while other parts are acting passive still holding 
information and waiting to receive information in cycles of 12.5 to 30 
transitions or cycles per second.  Otherwise if your brain lit up to 
heavily not only would calories be burnt very quickly, the very function of 
the brain would stop working properly. Like going into seizure or just 
simply unconsciousness.  Some animals that have very primitive/oddly 
evolved brains like opossums where their brains can actually have too much 
bursting activity that can make them seizure; particularly too much 
activity between left and right brain lobes. It has served the possum well 
enough as it just sits as if its dead.

I know from experience that the human brain is an amazing organ, which 
needs to be nourished and protected and never taken for granted. Two years 
a go I had a 'normal' every day virus ( mild ear infection), which decided 
to attack me and my brain! It destroyed the Myelin Sheath which insulated 
the neuron, thus enabling my right leg to move ~ in lay man terms I forgot 
how to walk. Literally over night. I went to get out of bed and fell to the 
floor. It took 6 months + to learn to move my leg correctly, but my amazing 
brain did it. It re-routed and now uses another 'dormant' Neuron. To say 
that I am happy that I had dormant neurons, which didn't do a great deal 
and just sat there waiting to be used is an understatement. I'm very 
pleased that my brain only works to under 10%.... to tell you the truth, 
when I had my first MRI I was ecstatic that they found a brain at all :)

+RoboBoddicker I am not referring to infectious diseases like bacteria of 
virus based disease, nor am I suggesting to eat raw meat. However, animals 
do eat raw meat and do not get sick. Most diseases caught from raw fruits 
and veggies are caused by run off of animal farms or poor storage 
conditions.  I am referring to diseases like cancer, heart disease, liver 
problems, adrenal problems and in general organ related illness. Cooked 
food would also refer to processed foods as well. Raw food diseases are 
typically related to poor handling in some way.  

Raw foods are better for the body in that they contain enzymes. Enzymes are 
produced by the body when needed, but most wild animals produce few if any, 
this is because they get them in their daily diet.  Because of cooking and 
processing most humans have an enzyme deficient diet.  Enzymes break down 
in heat and in general over time, therefore any food that is cooked is 
enzyme deficient,  When the body has to produce enzymes the liver enlarges 
and organs that produce enzymes are constantly working to pump them out. 
The body can only produce so many enzymes in one lifetime. This slow 
process leads to many diseases we have today.  Cooked food is not easier to 
digest because of the lack of enzymes, raw food digests itself therefore 
the body can do other things like produce energy for the brain etc.

top_comment.text:
I must respectably doubt the conclusion that multitasking is not possible 
for energy-saving reasons. There is a ton of things that everyone 
constantly multitasks and many of which are complex enough that computers 
cannot or are challenged with doing. Consider the example of Driving and 
having a Conversation with someone next to you. You don't have any computer 
that can have a conversation with you and interpret natural language like a 
person. You also only now have prototypes of self-driving cars that can 
outperform most humans. Now, how come we can do both? At the same time? 
Compete on multitasking with a women and you will find you lose most of the 
time. A simple change of gender (that is not simple at all), improves 
multitasking extensively and yet I'm sure it's not because she gets more 
neurons activated at a certain moment. In my understanding, multitasking 
depends highly on coordination of smaller tasks. Coordination on your brain 
can never stop, it might be underloaded or reduce frequency but it would be 
caos if it stopped. The reason we can multitask complex things with 
practice is that the unconscious progressively learns some coordination of 
and offloads the conscious coordination. That's why with practice you only 
think "I'm heading home" and you find yourself parking your car there 
without being aware of the subtleties of clutch-accelerator-break 
equilibrium. So in my view, we are outstanding machines in regards to 
multitasking. And again, I sincerely doubt that it has anything to do with 
energy management.﻿

comments.text:
Well... If you change the definition of multitasking I have to give it to 
you. But I ask myself if that definition is good for anything. The only way 
I could have multitasking in the way you express is with two disconnected 
brains instead of a coordinated one. Switching between coordination of 
tasks is the only way we can get it done on a computer no matter how many 
cores you have. Coordination is by definition a centralization problem. 
Parallelization of work is not always possible. Two good examples are the 
calculation of prime numbers and the calculation of Fibonacci numbers, 
because they are series defined by their previous instantiations. (by the 
way, there is a prize on the first that would make you millionaire... And 
also break the foundations of modern cryptography). So when you say that 
this definition is fallacious or a gross exaggeration you are missing the 
point that even if we were perfect parallel machines we skill wouldn't 
operate in full paralell mode. By the way you might find interesting the 
theory of "thin slicing". I read about it in a book from Malcolm Gladwell 
named "Blink, the power of thinking without thinking". Thanks for sharing 
you opinion. If you want me to elaborate on anything you disagree or where 
I wasn't clear just question it ;)
comments.author: João Osório

comments.text:
That is solid thinking, but they have actually done some research on the 
lack of multi-tasking that occurs in instances such as driving and talking 
on the phone. However, I agree in that by the definition of multi-tasking, 
you would be doing such, but as far as neuroscience is concerned, 
inattentively driving down the road while listening to someone talk is not 
true multi-tasking. Looking at it physiologically, the brain switches 
between the two tasks very quickly, allowing you to stay on the road and 
understand the phone call, however in every instant, one is only doing both 
activities at a fractional efficiency. The more things you do at time, the 
more poorly you will do at all of them, even if it doesn't show so 
obviously as driving off the road. Women's brains are better at switching 
from one area of attention to another, thus making them more efficient at 
performing multiple tasks at once, however the same effect occurs. memory 
of the phone call is significantly decreased, and lack of attention to the 
road causes terrible reaction time and a lack of awareness of surroundings. 
And breaking down these tasks to simple functions that occur at once, such 
as the pedals of a car and the clutch, is a logical fallacy in itself, as 
you could say each of our cells is performing multiple functions, thus we 
are performing millions or more tasks at once. I know that's a gross 
exaggeration, but the point is when we learn to drive, all of those tasks 
are learned as one. Someone who learned to operate gas, then brake, then 
clutch, with never using all three at the same time, would be terrible at 
driving. It is all bundled into one task, as far as our brain is concerned. 
When it comes to your main point of energy management, I can't completely 
disagree with  that, because I do think other variables are involved.
comments.author: fourPOdimethylT

comments.text:
We use 100% of our brain. 
The 16% referred is how much the various of the brain or undergoing large 
amounts of electrical activity; specifically in the outer part such as 
cerebrum used for thinking. Inner parts of the brain is always working such 
as involuntary actions of heart and breathing as well as other parts 
receiving inputs or waiting for inputs like hearing, seeing, sense of 
touch, smelling, etc. at their individual cycles.
Cerebrum brain cycles very quickly: waking consciousness ranges from 12.5 
to 30 transitions or cycles per second.  
And new studies show both grey matter which is the smallest portion of the 
brain once thought to be only places where neurons formed memories and 
other complex activities appears to be wrong.  White matter are of the 
cerebrum has been observed to change shape over time after learning motor 
activities. 
http://io9.com/5681378/mysterious-white-matter-may-be-more-important-than-gray-matter-in-your-brain
So we use all of the brain. And it cycles very quickly.
Essentially, the 16% is describing how large bursting activity happens in a 
series instead of all at once in cycles.  But if all of your brain wasn't 
working; it wouldn't receive those bursting cycles up to 30 every second 
and continue the brain activity.  And if all of the brain lit up 100%; 
likely many of the interrogative parts of the brain that specialize in many 
areas such as speech, motor function, facial recognition, etc. would get 
too much  cross information (some parts of the brain and concept forming 
use same regions or mixture of regions for different things so data would 
get mixed up) causing you to ignore the stimulus of 100% burst activity, 
unconsciousness, seizures, spasm, or become extremely confused and 
disoriented until it was reduced back to the lower numbers mentioned in the 
video.
Analogy to turning all transistor paths on a computer to on. You'd get 
scrambled confusion... just an analogy but it'd be something like that.

comments.text:
Practically it will over-heat, get over-exhausted and the cells will start 
to die.
Now, just for the sake of argument, assume that you can somehow make the 
cells such that they can survive in this overheated and exhaustive mode. 
Then, all that processing of information throughout the entire brain will 
be highly unstructured, will be extremely jumbled up, and will not contain 
any meaningful, structured information or processing. Just a bunch of 
active neurons and electric currents do not make the brain what it is -- 
the structure in that information and the sequential pattern in the 
processing of it does.
As an analogy, just having more matter packed in a region does not make 
complex structures such as life forms easier to make. It requires the 
wiggle room for that to happen.
comments.author: subh1

comments.text:
+manish goel Definitely a discussable question. There were lots of smart 
reasonings given by many folks above. I think you need a little more open 
mindedness to absorb and analyse their views. Different tasks require 
different sets of neurons to fire and it is a highly inter-connected 
network. Even if you are able to supply the brain with infinite energy or 
even just over-feed, it is of no use because you cannot simply force a 
brain to work harder. When was the last time your brain was activated many 
folds just because you ate too much food? You have to ask yourself whether 
activating the whole brain is really necessary. Why would you want to drive 
a car home and at the same time cook or to remember your nightmares, and 
millions of other things? The perception will simply be too chaotic and 
will lead to nothing but failure in what you had to do (i.e. drive home). 
Most multi-tasking would most likely involve some common set of neurons to 
fire. If there is a over-lap of inputs from two different tasks on the same 
neuron/set of neurons, the brain will automatically tag confusion and you 
cannot perform well. There is reason to how our brain has evolved in this 
way to be better efficient in one work at a time. I love the human brain as 
it is. It's just that we have to understand how it works in order to excel 
at our tasks.

comments.text:
+Richard E. Cytowic  First of all, I am honored that you find my idea 
interesting.
Well, I never actually thought about how to supply infinite energy as I am 
more curious about what could we achive if we somehow do it. What would be 
the capabilities or limitiations of brain in such a scenario.
Anyway, I would try to answer your question to the best of my understanding.
I dont think that applying infinite energy instantaneously (using 
electricity etc) would do any good. The "10% at a time" limitation is 
induced by nature so that the body could sustain energy hungry brain. But, 
what if we start overfeeding it. Brain feeds on glucose like the entire 
body. An athelete needs extra glucose cause he consumes more. Same can be 
the case with brain. If we supply increased amount of sugar in a controlled 
way and force our brain to "exercise", that is to activate more than one of 
regions at a particular instant, we might be able to extend the limits. I 
guess, what I meant to say is to force the brain to evolve. It would take 
years to make changes, but I dont think that million years of evolution 
could be reversed in seconds. The possible faults in the idea:
1) altering glucose balance can be harmful.
2) changes in an individual wont be transferred to its progeny, i.e. 
everything would need to be started again.
3) Brain might not actually change.

Now, if we are impatient and we want to do it in seconds only. Then, we can 
flood our brain with 'some' molecule which can act as an alternative source 
of energy for neurons and has the property of ~100% renewability based on 
energy input from other source of unharmful energy. UV rays can cause DNA 
mutation, it might be possible to find a energy providing molecule which 
replenishes itself using energy from, for example: ultrasound.

comments.text:
An interesting question, Manesh. But how do you propose to "apply infinite 
energy to the brain?" Relatively speaking, electroshock, lightning strikes, 
and the electric chair deliver infinite energy to the brain and destroy it. 
Even electrode implants first Parkinson's disease or seizure management 
disrupt intrinsic energy circuits; these external sources do not add energy 
to the nervous system.
   How, then, might you imagine overcoming the intrinsic power limitations, 
as well as a thermodynamic limits?
    Much research already shows that multitasking degrades performance, 
especially in those who believe themselves to be excellent at it. So, how 
do you get past this empirical finding as well as "force" multiple regions 
to work simultaneously? They already do, except not all at once which is 
the point of the brain's energy efficiency.
     Your idea has merit, and I'd like to hear how you propose implementing 
it in a practical way.
comments.author: Richard E. Cytowic

comments.text:
But we already use 100% of our brain (not simultaneously) and we already 
are capable of stimulate multiple regions together (you do drive+sing to a 
tune+think about dinner at the same time). You really do not need more than 
this. The crazy multitasking capacity of computers is not something human 
beings should necessarily seek. It's not very interesting IRL and look at 
it this way: you already have one of the best computing device between your 
two ears, it has gone through trial and error for millions of generations. 
Many animals have two cores ( dolphins have half the brain sleeping for a 
few hours and the other half for a few more hours, a lot of birds too) yet 
those animals have a lower intelligence than humans. There maybe is a 
purely efficiency based reason for not being able to multitask or only have 
1/2 sleep times like those animals)

plant nutrients more available.

comments.text:
+Marc Paul Rubin I am not deeply familiar with the argument regarding the 
evolution of ape to human brains requiring cooking (which implies meat 
consumption, because cooking does not increase calories, but allows humans 
to better digest meat).

It seems to me that evolution should only require the same amount of 
calories as to sustain a brain of the same size (in terms of number of 
neurons). Thus, such statements imply that plant-based and raw diets are 
"unnatural", and that it's not possible to get enough calories on such 
diets to fuel the huge human brain. This is not the case.

Of course industrial food production makes it easier for everyone (no 
matter what they eat) to get more calories now than early in our history.

Just as the idea of us using 10% of our brains became a cultural value, 
even more so engrained is the idea that humans are meant to consume dead 
flesh.

I suppose I'm saying we should always be suspicious when science reinforces 
cultural norms.

Shall we take on hemispherical asymmetry next? ;)

comments.text:
+EmXtraMoney Those percentages represent the daily glucose consumption of 
the brain compared to each individual's body mass. That means if a brain 
consumes X glucose, in a body that has body mass equal to 50 kg, the 
percentage is much higher than X in a body that has body mass equal to 
100kg. X represents the same quantity of daily glucose. 

More exactly, a lower body mass means less resources, so a higher 
percentage of consumption is acquired. But only the percentage changes, 
while the quantity remains the same. For example, if you have two buckets 
filled with water, one that contains 500 l, and the other 200 l, and you 
need to drink 100 l to live; if you drink from the 500 l bucket, that means 
that you used 20%, whereas if you drink from the 200 l bucket, that means 
that you used 50%.

comments.text: It's true, only if you use your brain at the minimum capacity all the time.
comments.author: serbest cagrisim

top_comment.text:
I am interested in brain transplants, I hope that will be an option in the 
future.﻿
top_comment.author: NatureGoddess

comments.text:
+NatureGoddess 
It's more precise to say body transplant, because if your brain is 
transplanted to another body, that will be you in another body. The brain 
defines who we are. 
As far as I know it is possible to transplant body to a head, but the 
problem is that they can't figure out how to restore nerves, in particular 
the spinal chorde. So the subject will be paralyzed from the neck down.
comments.author: log1c91

comments.text:
Seriously, was there a successful brain transplant without consequences? 
Because that would be awesome.
comments.author: NatureGoddess

comments.text: Dude. Brain transplants are already a thing.
comments.author: 4gnomesx3

top_comment.text:
So can we work out a way to fire more neurons at once given unlimited 
access to food? Are fat people just smarter, on average? Does access to 
food mean that wealthy nations are just inherently smarter? ﻿
top_comment.author: Michael Currier

comments.text:
+Bruno Martynhak 1- So does that imply an absolute limit on intelligence? 
2- Figures. 3- I understand the socio-economic gap (which includes the 
education gap) is the major contributor. But you'd think that consistent 
access to more than enough food would allow someone to use their brain as 
often as they could, instead of being limited by hunger. Using your brain 
more often surely means becoming smarter.

The effects of subsistence on adult development should be significant, even 
if as a child and adolescent plenty of food had been available. Just 
probably not the most significant.
comments.author: Michael Currier

comments.text:
1- Maybe. But the signal-to-noise ratio would be worse. With even more 
neurons firing together you could also have seizure. 2- No. 3-There is a 
point, specially during development of the brain. But you can't really 
compare, because they have different levels of education.
comments.author: Bruno Martynhak
